Ang pelikulang Hello, Love, Goodbye ay isang nakakaantig na kwento tungkol sa pag-ibig at mga sakripisyong ginawa para sa mga pangarap. Ang paggamit ng Filipino sa mga emosyonal na eksena ay kapansin-pansin sa pelikulang ito, na nagbigay ng mas malalim na koneksyon sa mga manonood. Ang mga linya ay natural at totoo, kaya ang mga emosyon ng mga karakter ay higit na nadarama. Gayunpaman, may ilang bahagi kung saan ang mga diyalogo ay may halong Ingles, na bagama't nagbibigay ng makabagong tono, ay nakakabawas sa lalim ng mensahe sa wikang Filipino. Sa aking palagay, maganda pa rin ang paggamit ng Filipino sa pelikulang ito dahil ito ay nagpapakita ng ating wika na nagpapahayag ng tunay na damdamin at karanasan. Para lalo pang pagbutihin, makabubuting bigyang pansin ang paggamit ng mas malalim at mas masining na mga salita sa Filipino upang mas maipakita ang yaman at kagandahan ng ating sariling wika.

A romance drama that shows the bitter reality of people trying to chase their dreams in tough situations. Actors Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards are sensational and display immaculate chemistry. The realistic story about love/dreams, will touch your heart and soul. As someone who is half Filipino, it was eye opening experience to witness the hardships of my culture. Hello, Love, Goodbye is a great romance drama filled with hard truths and reality. But with added beauty and pain to create a wonderful film. So I saw the sequel to this film Hello, Love, Again currently in theaters first. It was my introduction to Philippines cinema. Once I was informed on twitter that thereâ€™s a first film, I decided to check it out. The plot of Hello, Love, Goodbye is pretty clear cut. Set in Hong Kong, a Filipina domestic helper working hard to make the move to Canada meets a Filipino bartender trying to help his family. Even with the truth and circumstances laid out these two are drawn to each other. Leading to a honest portrayal of love, with all the highs and lows that come attached with it. It was refreshing to see a story feature characters who donâ€™t have everything together and are also struggling. Made things feel more genuine and authentic to me. Especially prominent in the brief little joys, no pun intended and adventures they partake in to escape their reality This film did a good job of hitting you hard in the feels. Some might not like how it ended but I did. If you are a dreamer like myself, it made perfect sense. Only gripe is the humor, majority of it, isnâ€™t my cup of tea. I really have to commend actor Kathryn Bernardo for giving us such a gripping performance as Joy. Her character goes through so much that she has to endure to maintain focus on her dream. Luckily Kathryn Bernardo really gave her best to convey the various emotions of Joyâ€™s situation brilliantly. She had the best performance in the movie. Her co-star Alden Richards matched her incredible acting and energy with his character Ethan. Unlike Joy, I was conflicted a lot with his character and at times wasnâ€™t a fan of his actions. But we can all relate to Ethan because love makes you do strange things. However Alden Richards adds a lot of charm and sincerity to Ethan. Hello, Love, Goodbye is an excellent romance drama from the Philippines. Even though itâ€™s ingrained fully into its culture, it can be easily enjoyed by everyone. For we all have been in similar situations when it comes to relationships, dreams and love. Iâ€™ve always maintained that the best romance films arenâ€™t the ones that give you the typical happy ending. This is what makes Hello, Love, Goodbye beautiful. if you love me, why cant you choose?if you love me, why are you making me choose?filipino romance movies always felt really corny to me as a filo american, especially with those low quality cheesy montages and lines. but i always had a soft spot for them, especially due to how skilled filipinos are when it comes to implementing the perfect amount of drama and sentiment into their entertainment.this movie was pretty solid to me when considering how i was never into these type of movies. ive watched a good amount of filo romance movies and like i said, i was never a big fan. which is why i was surprised when i found myself appreciating this movie for different aspects and executions.first of all, reminds me a lot of la la land (2016) except filipino OFW version. as much as it hurts, i like to treasure those bittersweet or â€œtragicâ€ love stories because its realistic. i live for the realism; the hope and joy whilst feeling that agony and yearning, bc i think it really shows u how things really are for a lot of relationships and couples; the reality. how it was never just about love and trust, but understanding. understanding your significant other, and how even when you guys do, the ending isnt always going to be â€œhappyâ€. i think its a common plot and ive def seen it before!! i just enjoyed this execution and i liked the mature take on it. this movie felt like an entire leap of maturity for both the characters (esp ethan) and shows the growth of their relationship and of them as people. i also loved their chemistry, alden richards and kathryn bernardo as the main couple. i was honestly surprised bc i grew up watching some of kaths films and thought she never had a romance one without that daniel padilla dude. and i am NOT mad that i was wrong bc i rlly liked alden and kathryn together. they delivered the emotional scenes incredibly and i js loved watching them. i also appreciate another bare minimum feature (that kinda ties into what i was just talking about) but multi dimension. like i said, ive seen the plot been done and its nothing groundbreaking or revolutionary. but this movie specifically also had me looking at both sides, both dimensions, and understanding both. i saw how there wasnt a bad guy nor a good guy, how both were multi dimensional and had their reasons. i just loved how it was very clear and how raw certain scenes were.im giving it only 3 n a half stars tho bc i js still found myself cringing like hell everytime alden richards character was being creepy af and IDK theres js this vibe ab filo movies i cant get over. #lovebeingpinoy tho

It wanted to be an OFW story, a love story, and a Filipino story. You know what? Itâ€™s actually pretty good for the most part. I still wouldâ€™ve preferred a slightly different ending that still retains Joy getting to follow her dreams of moving to Canada, but color me surprised even with the positive reactions, I didnâ€™t hate this. As much as I disliked Aldenâ€™s character (and his acting. Iâ€™m so sorry), itâ€™s a great decision to actually have him learn rather than have men like him win in the story even if they are actually wrong. Still, I am quite mixed on several aspects of the film. Script-wise, for one, I am aware that this is a romance film but I ended up being more interested in the OFW subplot. I have merely seen the trailer of Sunday Beauty Queen but parts of this instantly reminded me of that film. To bring forward a topic such as that in a mainstream film is a nice change of pace; however, it is instantly forgotten about and left unexplored by the second half. Some may say that the film already needed more time dedicated to the romance plot but I wish it was a little more consequential to tie itself to its OFW subplot. The dialogue is a little too on-the-nose at times as well, which can make some scenes feel a little superficial. Please get rid of full English dialogue between our pure Filipino leads, please, unless absolutely necessary (in which case, it wasn't).In terms of cinematography, I found it to be on and off. There are some good shots with impressive lighting here and there, yet they are never consistent as there are also shots that are too overexposed and poorly lit for my liking. I am aware that the motifs in the score would always be based off of a mainstream song, but having heard Kung 'Di Rin Lang Ikaw even months before this film's initial release (high school tingz), I find it to be a little overplayed at some points. Oh, and louder music doesn't always mean more emotional impact!Still, I guess the film's biggest redeeming point is its direction. Yes, it's a mainstream romance film, but it offers different flavor through its more mature approach. Spotty dialogue aside, the more emotional scenes work well on their own and never feel forced, even if they are a little too on the nose. I did not feel the chemistry of Kathryn Bernardo and Alden Richards at first, but damn it, Kathryn can carry hard. She just knows how to ground her character so well without making it feel superficial. Some people are probably tired of the comedic 'sidekick' best friend(s) of the lead female character but I personally found Kakai Bautista to be hilarious. Not all of her jokes land, but when they do, it's absolutely funny (the Vilma Santos scene probably got the loudest laugh out of me). And holy fuck, I knew that was Jameson Blake playing Peter! Why is he just so good at everything, even in playing an annoying character?Everything said here may have come across as if the negatives outweight the positives but Hello, Love, Goodbye is thankfully saved by Garcia-Sampana's (no longer Garcia-Molina) honest direction and Bernardo's strong acting. Perhaps its approach to showing the OFW life in Hong Kong can be shallow, but it's a good first step to bringing that story tied with its main romance plot into a mainstream Filipino film. Other aspects are quite weak (God, I'm sorry, but I couldn't stand Alden's acting), and perhaps a slightly different ending would have sufficed, yet by the end of it, it didn't feel poorly-made for the sake of profit. By utilizing the appeal of the two leads from their own different loveteams to tell a new romance story, it gets its point across effectively. Once the credits have rolled, I was relieved that I did not hate it, even if it's not quite my thing.P.S.
